message:
I'm working with the vim-surround plugin and this HTML...
  • *#005462
    • where the * is my cursor. I'd like to surround the #005462 with so it looks like this, #005462. I can do this with visual mode but would like to do something I can repeat with the dot operator. Any advice?
Like most things in vim, "w" (move a word) takes a count, so 2w means move 2 words.
So 2w is what you're looking for.

By the way, I would use something else in this situation:
f;
I.e. move the cursor forward until it reaches the next ";"

It's much easier, since once you get used to just looking where you want the cursor to end up, then you can use it without thinking. Better than counting how many words forward you want to move. (But it might not work properly with the "." operator, so there are downsides)
also 't'. I use t< quite a bit.

command break down:
ys: to surround an element
it: inner tag
<code>: the tag to surround

If you're using surround plugin, you could use "t" for tag-based object selection. So to achieve what you want:
ysit<code>
